6.10.23  12:40 am   what is the best?

      the most good

6.9.23  11:31 pm   I wrote a song as a lead sheet and want to know how long it is. It's 112 measures long, in 4/4, and 119 BPM. How can I gauge how long it is, without having an opportunity to record it. With Math?

      4/4 means 4 beats per bar, and it's 112 bars, so 112 x 4 = 448 beats in the whole song. at 119 beats per minute, ... 448 divided by 119 means 3.76 minutes. about 3 minutes and 3 quarters of a minute. so that's 3 minutes and 45 seconds

      how about directing it

6.9.23  3:28 pm   I try to use the "make something bad" technique very frequently, since I can see its merit, but every time I find myself wanting to put in effort because something sounds kinda cool for a second. however, this just sticks me back at square one because then I'm """trying""" when I'm supposed to be using the not trying trick. I hope you see what I mean there. in short: when using the "make it bad" trick, how can I overcome the need to make it good?

      if you say it starts sounding good for a moment, that means the trick is working, in that moment. however, that also immediately makes it stop working, so you have to keep re-setting the trick

6.9.23  3:25 am   Why do I always fall in love with people I shouldn't?

6.9.23  2:54 am   so, i've spent a while trying to figure out the chords to the first verse of "i like to wear soft clothing", and i ended up with this for the first 8 bars after the intro:

Bb6 Cm7 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bb6 C7sus4 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bbadd9 Cm7 | Dm F7sus2sus4 | Bb7 Cm7 | Dm F6

     there's no way those 1 chords are 6's. that should be Bbmaj7. and there's no way the 2 chord is C7sus4 the second time around. should be the same as the first time. this is just a repeating cycle. any variations are up to the players, but still, that second Cmin7 chord would certainly never be missed

     it seems to mostly repeat with minor variations. i did come across one kinda odd thing, though: in the 6th bar, on "me", the vocal is on a D, but there's something playing an Eb a minor 9th above it. i didn't really know what to make of that, so i just picked the Eb to put in the chord and left the D out of it

     sure that's fine, although it's fairly likely that the guitar is doing like Ebmaj7 (with F in the bass, or the bass may be doing G to A there. i don't recall)

     a lot of this is probably spectacularly wrong (some of those notes feel REALLY quiet - hell, i may have started making them up at a certain point), so i'd love any feedback you may have. thanks!

     i'd prefer not to listen to it at this moment because listening to the recordings can bring up some anxiety for me, so i'll only speak about it from memory, but i'd have to assume that the guitar/chord part is probably just repeating 2 voicings (Bbmaj7, Ebmaj7), and then the bass mostly probably will go 1, 2 to start (or sometimes maybe 1, 4), and then often 3, 4-5. or sometimes 5, 6-7. i'm also aware that i forgot to do it the way i wrote it. the way i meant it to be, for the bass, was more like 1, 4, 5, 6-7. OR sometimes maybe 1, 2, 5, 2-5. in actual reality, when i got on the bass, i just played the song instinctively and forgot about the specific chord choices i'd made when writing it before

6.7.23  8:46 pm   why do i see 4/4 + 5/4 a lot comparatively to 9/4

      9/4 makes the bar huge. you could be part way through the bar and it's like you're swimming in an ocean. you might even forget when the bar started, it's so long ago

6.7.23  6:32 pm   Would you say the intro to the on the ground plane song is minor?

     not quite. i'd say it's main identity seems to be in the grey area between mixolydian and dorian. even so, it still borrows a flat 6 and even a flat 2 momentarily

     I realise that it's sus most of the time but the melody lands on the flat 3 on "like" in the lyric "I don't like it". 

     yeah but that doesn't count for as much because it's on the 4 chord
